docs.lead_paragraph: Sy Sternberg, the chairman of New York Life Insurance, is in China this week trying to figure out whom to meet so as to ensure that his company is next among the dozens of insurers who have applied for a license to do business in China. ''We don't know what the process is in awarding licenses,'' said Mr. Sternberg, though New York Life has devoted more resources than almost any other American insurer to securing the right to operate here. He has tried to touch all the bases -- from officials of the China Insurance Regulatory Commission to Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. Still, he cannot be sure that he has met the person who makes the final decision.

headline.main: With Trade Links Stronger, U.S. Insurers Scout for Business in China

docs.abstract: US insurers are scouting for business in China with trade links stronger; bureaucratic scene remains tricky, but new openness is promised; some insurance companies looking to enter Chinese market include New York Life Insurance Co, Cigna Corp and American International Group; Sy Sternberg of New York Life comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert P. Casey, the governor of Pennsylvania from 1987 to 1994, whose strong opposition to abortion put him at odds with the Democratic Party, died yesterday in Scranton, where he lived. He was 68. The cause was an infection.

headline.main: Former Gov. Robert P. Casey Dies at 68; Pennsylvania Democrat Opposed Abortion

docs.abstract: Robert P Casey, governor of Pennsylvania from 1987 to 1994, dies at age 68; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Robert P. Casey, the governor of Pennsylvania from 1987 to 1994, whose strong opposition to abortion put him at odds with the Democratic Party, died yesterday in Scranton, where he lived. He was 68.     The cause was an infection.

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 35,000 Bell Atlantic workers in New York and New England announced yesterday that it had called off a strike scheduled for today after the company agreed to rescind changes it had ordered in the workers' health plans. Even though the union's contract does not expire until Aug. 5, the union, the Communications Workers of America, called for the strike out of anger that Bell Atlantic had increased co-payments for the workers' health maintenance organization plans.

headline.main: Union at Bell Atlantic Calls Off Strike Over Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Bickering this election year between Democrats and Republicans over a drug benefit for Medicare enrollees has been shrill. But Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, two influential leaders on health care, announced a set of principles last week that, by blurring the distinction between the parties, might yield compromise. Mr. Wyden and Mr. Thomas agreed that any Medicare drug benefit should be a universal benefit to which the elderly are legally entitled. That might seem innocuous. But Mr. Wyden's efforts will be opposed by Democrats who want to head into November with no agreement. Mr. Thomas will win little applause in the Republican caucus for embracing the proposition that what America needs is another federal entitlement.
docs.abstract: Editorial says proposal by Democratic Sen Ron Wyden and Republican Repr Bill Thomas, that any Medicare drug benefit be universal benefit to which elderly are legally entitled, might yield compromise in Congress; says it serves as worthy guideline for policy (S)
docs.snippet: Bickering this election year between Democrats and Republicans over a drug benefit for Medicare enrollees has been shrill. But Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, two influential leaders on...

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-four hospitals in suburban and upstate New York have filed a civil suit accusing Aetna U.S. Healthcare Inc., a managed care company, of breaching contracts through routine late payment of claims, a lawyer for the plaintiffs said yesterday. The company is a unit of Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer. Aetna is based in Hartford. The lawsuit seeks $95 million in compensatory and punitive damages. It is believed to be the first time that a large number of hospitals in a region have joined together to seek payments from a managed care company, said Fred Miller, a lawyer who filed the suit on Friday in State Supreme Court in New York.

headline.main: Metro Business; Hospitals Sue Aetna On Payment Claims

docs.lead_paragraph: Social insurance began in Europe, principally in Germany in the Bismarck era. In 1911, Winston Churchill carried unemployment insurance in the House of Commons, representing the Liberal government. The Tories opposite said the workers would spend the money on drink; Churchill said it was their money. Whereupon a first principle was established. The American Association for Labor Legislation, an academic group, was established in 1906. Workers' compensation laws began to appear. Soon, in Albany, Al Smith and Robert F. Wagner brought us ''mothers' pensions'' and the like.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Sen Daniel Patrick Moynihan backs proposals for voluntary, contributory savings plans in Social Security system, which he says will enable Americans to end working lives with measure of wealth; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With bipartisan political support and a growing national awareness of public health issues, the Irish government is taking aggressive steps that could result in Ireland being the first European country to seek damages from tobacco companies for the cost of treating smoking-related illnesses. In April, Irish lawyers and members of Parliament traveled to New Orleans to seek advice from people involved in the landmark American tobacco settlements, including Hubert H. Humphrey III, the former attorney general of Minnesota, and Ron Motley, a leading plaintiffs' lawyer. A parliamentary health committee will soon begin investigating whether three Irish tobacco companies knew about research by their American parent companies into the dangers of smoking and the addictive nature of nicotine.

headline.main: Ireland May Sue for Smoking Illnesses

docs.abstract: Irish government is taking aggressive steps that could result in Ireland being first European country to seek damages from tobacco companies for cost of treating smoking-related illnesses; Irish officials are seeking advice from people involved in US lawsuit settlements (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate race in New Jersey, lately overshadowed by the recent political drama in New York, now moves to center stage with two hotly contested primary elections on June 6. Voters must choose Democratic and Republican nominees for a general-election contest that could figure in the battle for control of the Senate. The Democratic race offers a choice between Jon Corzine, an earnest, big-spending political novice, and Jim Florio, a battle-scarred but knowledgeable former governor.

headline.main: The Senate Primary in New Jersey

docs.abstract: Editorial endorses former Gov Jim Florio as Democratic nominee for US Senate seat from New Jersey and US Repr Bob Franks as Republican nominee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We were disappointed by Henry Wong's May 24 Op-Ed article, ''Help China and Help Chinatown.'' His mother's unionized garment job has supported the family, providing health insurance and other benefits, and Mr. Wong is currently receiving a $250-a-year textbook scholarship from Unite Local 23-25.

docs.lead_paragraph: What a difference a candidate makes. In state budget talks in April, the Legislature was prepared to have New York join a new program to let thousands of disabled people stay on Medicaid, the federal health insurance plan for the poor, even after getting jobs. But Gov. George E. Pataki's office balked at the cost, and the plan was dropped, apparently dead for the year.

headline.main: Politics Bring Lazio's Plan For Disabled Back to Life

docs.abstract: Rep Rick Lazio's Senate candidacy has revived plan for New York State to join new program Lazio sponsored to let disabled people remain on Medicaid after getting jobs, if they do not earn more than $45,000 a year; Gov George E Pataki, who had balked at cost, is reconsidering to boost Lazio (M)
